awd_titl_txt: Conference: Gordon Research Conference in Centromere Biology
awd_abstract_narration:
Centromeres remain perhaps the most enigmatic regions of the eukaryotic genome, despite their critical role as the foundation for chromosome segregation during every eukaryotic cell division. The importance of centromeres in genome inheritance has long been recognized, but their properties, organization, and variability have remained mysterious. Indeed, despite the “complete sequencing” of the human genome more than a decade ago, it was only recently that the first assembly of a human centromere was completed. This advance is now allowing researchers to harness this sequence information to tackle fundamental questions on centromere properties and behavior. The proposed Gordon Research Seminar and Conference will stimulate discussions to consider how the field will need to build upon centromere DNA sequence information towards understanding the increasing complexity in structure and function. This conference will act as an important catalyst for the centromere field to generate a unique conceptual framework to address these questions, together with tools and technologies that combine genome, computational and bioinformatics approaches, and complementary functional biological studies at the molecular, cellular, and organismal levels. The Broader Impacts of effort include the intrinsic merit of the research as all eukaryotic cells rely on centromeres during cell division. In addition, training and networking opportunities will be provided for the next generation of researchers. 

Proper centromere function requires a complex cascade of biochemical events to direct chromatin and kinetochore assembly and involves hundreds of different proteins. However, the precise mechanisms that integrate the genetic and biochemical events leading to functional centromeres are still largely unknown. Kinetochore formation during mitosis depends upon the specialized centromeric chromatin in which histone H3 nucleosomes are replaced with nucleosomes containing the centromeric histone Centromere Protein A (CENP-A). Failure to load CENP-A into centromeres each cell cycle ultimately leads to centromere loss, kinetochore failure, chromosome mis-segregation and cell death. Defects in centromere function and the resulting chromosome segregation errors lead to chromosome aneuploidy, a hallmark of many afflictions. Over the past decade, centromere researchers have identified some of the key factors that control centromere protein assembly and the epigenetic maintenance of centromeric chromatin. However, we lack a clear understanding of how these factors come together to generate centromeres at a specific locus through each cell division cycle and this conference and associated seminar will bring together researchers to discuss strategic directions that are needed to advance our understanding of this important region of the genome.
This conference is co-sponsored by the Cellular Dynamics and Function together with the Genetic Mechanisms program, both within the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We are pleased to provide an update on the third Gordon Research Seminar (GRS) on ?Centromere Biology?, which was held in the summer of 2022. The conference was a great success and provided a platform for scientists to discuss new and late-breaking findings in the field of centromere biology, form close interactions and collaborations with each other, and advance their careers through important discussions. We particularly focused on enabling training experiences and participation from trainees.

 

Intellectual Merit:

The conference focused on genetic, epigenetic, structural, biochemical, and evolutionary aspects of centromere biology and the fundamental role of centromeres in chromosome segregation. It provided a unique opportunity for young scientists in the chromosome and centromere communities to discuss exciting and fast-paced findings in a rapidly moving field. The conference also served as an important catalyst for the centromere field to generate a unique conceptual framework to address questions surrounding centromere properties and behavior. The attendees discussed many topics, including how the field will need to build upon centromere DNA sequence information towards understanding the increasing complexity in structure and function.

 

Broader Impacts:

Our overarching goal was to provide trainees with valuable programs, interactions, and education towards their effective career development. We successfully highlighted exciting science, generated a collegial environment to stimulate interactions, and included a mentoring component to allow trainees to ?pay it forward? to assist new members of the centromere community through peer mentoring. The panel discussion on ?Enacting positive change in our spaces? brought together panelists who have been successful in advocating and implementing change to address inequities and make a positive difference, both in academia and in the broader scientific community. The panelists included Needhi Bhalla (University of California, Santa Cruz) and Kenneth Gibbs (National Institutes of Health).

Almost half of the participants at the meeting indicated that this was their first time for attendance at any GRC conference, let alone the Centromere Biology meeting. Overall, 43% of the attendees identified as female, and 57% identified as male, with a similar breakdown for the speakers (a substantially higher proportion of women speakers than other GRC meetings). Although the majority of the participants were white and based in the US, 8 participants identified as a member of historically underrepresented groups, including either hispanic or black. In addition, multiple of these individuals presented talks during the conference (with others giving posters). In total, the conference included almost 70 trainees (35 post-docs and 33 graduate students).  Funds from the NSF provided partial support for 21 participants, including 15 trainees and 6 trainee organizers who participated in the GRS portion of the conference (faculty participants).

We are pleased to report that the conference was successful in achieving our goals and objectives. The evaluation information through surveys adminstered by the GRC was also exceptionally positive, attesting to the valuable impace of this meeting. For example, the vast majority of attendees stayed for the entire conference at a rate that is even higher than other GRC meetings (where there are strong rules for this overall), and partiicpants rated the conference very highty overall for the program, speaker selection, presentations, and interactions.

Together we believe that the conference has led to important advances in the field of centromere biology and provided a unique opportunity for young scientists to form close interactions and collaborations with each other. We would like to express our gratitude to NSF for their support and look forward to continuing to advance the field of centromere biology in the future.
